learning_outcomes.description: Design and implement Networking (SDN-based or other) applications to implement a range of networking functionalities and services.
Demonstrate the application of Network Management concepts to practical computer networking scenarios.
Analyse and evaluate performance aspects of computer networks using queuing theory.
Apply peer-to-peer computing concepts to solve distributed computing problems.
Communicate with peers and work efficiently in a small team.
Analyse computer networking problems, and formulate and implement practical solutions, individually as well as in a small team.
Analyse and evaluate the functional and performance aspects of computer networks, including Software Defined Networks, using network emulation as an experimental platform.

assessments.task_description:
Students (in small teams) are required to undertake a research/implementation project on an advanced networking topic, e.g. SDN. 

This assessment item includes a project proposal and progress report.

Use of AI

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly and specifically reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students (in teams) will undertake an advanced networking project.

This assessment item consists of a final project report. 

Use of AI

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly and specifically reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
20/10/2025 - 31/10/2025

In Semester Week 12 or 13, at a time scheduled with the course coordinator
assessments.task_description:
A presentation/demo/interview (in Semester Week 12 or 13, at a time scheduled with the course coordinator)

In the Presentation/Interview/Demo component of the Project Part B assessment, teams will provide a verbal presentation of their project, with visual support (slides, etc.). The duration of the presentation should be around 10 minutes. If the project includes an implementation component, a demo of the implemented system will be provided. This is then followed by a Q&A session. 


Use of AI

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT 

may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
A final examination will be held as a traditional on-campus written exam, during the final examination period. 

This exam will be open-book and will contain a combination of multiple-choice, problem solving and short answer questions. 


Use of AI

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT 

may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Lectures in COMS6200 are designed to deliver the core theoretical content of the course. Typically held for 2 hours per week, these sessions introduce students to advanced concepts in computer networking, such as Software Defined Networking, Queuing Theory, and Wireless Networks. Lectures are led by the course coordinator and/or a lecturer and cover the foundational knowledge and principles required to understand complex network systems.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures Lectures in COMS6200 are designed to deliver the core theoretical content of the course. Typically held for 2 hours per week, these sessions introduce students to advanced concepts in computer networking, such as Software Defined Networking, Queuing Theory, and Wireless Networks. Lectures are led by the course coordinator and/or a lecturer and cover the foundational knowledge and principles required to understand complex network systems.

learning_activities.topic:
Applied Class

Applied Classes, are 1-hour weekly sessions that provide a smaller, interactive setting for students to deepen their understanding of lecture material. These sessions focus on applying theoretical concepts through problem-solving, discussions, and exercises. Applied classes often involve practice questions and are a chance to get feedback, clarify doubts, discuss upcoming assessments, and engage with peers.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Applied Class Applied Classes, are 1-hour weekly sessions that provide a smaller, interactive setting for students to deepen their understanding of lecture material. These sessions focus on applying theoretical concepts through problem-solving, discussions, and exercises. Applied classes often involve practice questions and are a chance to get feedback, clarify doubts, discuss upcoming assessments, and engage with peers.

learning_activities.topic:
Practicals

Practicals, are weekly hands-on classes where students apply theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios, in a computer lab environment. These sessions focus on developing technical skills, such as configuring Software Defined Network systems, or programming network applications. Students work individually, using lab facilities or, in some cases, personal computing equipment. These sessions are crucial for gaining experience with real-world Software Defined Networking tools and techniques.


Learning outcomes: L01, L06, L07
